title: The surprising truth about inattentive ADHD (that no one tells you)
subtitle: If your brain constantly feels like a browser with 57 open tabs, and one of them is playing thrash metal.
author: Rhys Morgan
content_html:
I didn’t know I had ADHD… until I realised I was losing my life to it

For years I thought I was lazy. Unmotivated. A bit useless.

I’d start stuff... then forget what I was doing halfway through.

Lose keys. Miss appointments. Say “sorry I’m late” more than I said “good morning.”

And the worst bit?

I thought it was my fault.

ADHD doesn’t always look like hyper kids and fidgeting

Nope. Sometimes it looks like...

  • staring at a to-do list for 4 hours

  • zoning out while someone’s talking to you

  • feeling like you’re not really “here”... even when you are

  • thinking “I’ll do that later” about 47 different things... and doing none

This is inattentive ADHD. And it’s sneaky.

It hides behind being polite.
Behind “she’s just a bit away with the fairies.”
Behind “he’s just disorganised.”

But the truth is... it messes with everything.

My brain wasn’t lazy… it was just overwhelmed

Here’s what no one tells you:
It’s not that we don’t care. We care too much.

It’s just that our brains are like magpies on Red Bull.
Something shiny flies by? We’re off.

Halfway through an email... oh look a squirrel.

Started cleaning the kitchen... now deep in a YouTube hole about 17th-century spoons.

Disorganisation isn’t a flaw… it’s a symptom

People say “just make a list.”
Mate. I make lists of my lists.
Then I lose them.

Or I write them on my phone, forget I wrote them… then start again from scratch.

I once found 6 notebooks.
All started. None finished.
It felt like a metaphor for my life.

Procrastination isn’t laziness either

It’s fear.
Of doing it wrong.
Of not doing it “right enough.”
Of failing before you even start.

So you freeze.
Or you clean your fridge instead.
(Which suddenly feels extremely important.)

Mindfulness helped me stop yelling at myself

I used to think mindfulness was for yoga mums and monks.

Then I tried it. Just 3 minutes of breathing.
And for the first time... silence.

Not full silence. But like someone turned down the volume a bit.

When I feel myself spiralling now... I breathe.
Deep and slow. Like I’m deflating a balloon.

Mindfulness didn’t cure me.
But it helps me come back to the moment...
before I disappear again.

ADHD isn’t the enemy — the shame is

We grow up hearing we’re too much.
Too loud. Too messy. Too disorganised. Too forgetful.

So we start to believe it.
We carry that shame into adulthood.

But ADHD isn’t a personality flaw.
It’s a wiring difference.

And when you learn how your brain works…
Everything changes.

You’re not broken. You’re wired differently.

There’s nothing wrong with needing reminders.
Timers. Lists. Sticky notes on your mirror.
Or someone to help you make sense of it all.

There’s nothing wrong with asking for help.

Because once you know what you’re working with…
You can work with it.

So if your brain feels like a washing machine on spin cycle…

You’re not alone.
You’re not lazy.
You’re not a failure.

You’re someone with ADHD.
And the more you understand it…
The more power you get back.

Final takeaway:

The day I stopped fighting my ADHD was the day I started winning.
Not in a perfect Instagram way.
In a messy, real-life, “I remembered to eat lunch today” kind of way.

And that counts.
